subject: URGENT: Your account has been suspended
body:
Dear Customer,

We noticed unusual activity on your account. Please click the link below to verify your identity or your account will be permanently locked in 24 hours.


Verify Account Now
explanation: Look closely at the sender address: 'paypa1-update.com' uses a number '1' instead of an 'l'. It also uses threatening language ('permanently locked') to create a false sense of urgency.

subject: Updated Holiday Schedule for 2026
body:
Hi Team,

Please find the updated holiday schedule for this year attached to the employee portal. Let us know if you have any questions.


Best,
Human Resources
explanation: This is a safe internal email. The sender domain matches the company, there is no urgent action required, and it doesn't ask for personal credentials.

subject: Mandatory Software Update
body:
All employees must install the latest security patch by end of day. Download the executable file below to update your system.


Download Patch.exe
explanation: Real IT departments usually push updates automatically. Downloading an '.exe' file directly from an email link is a classic malware delivery tactic.

subject: Missed Meeting Recording: Q1 Strategy Review
body:
Hello,

You missed a mandatory team meeting earlier today. The host has shared the recording with you. Please log in with your corporate credentials to view the video file.


View Recording
explanation: This is a credential harvesting attack. The sender domain 'zoom-meeting-invites.com' is fake (real is zoom.us), and it tries to force you to enter your corporate password on a fake login page.

subject: Lunch today?
body:
Hey!

Are you free for lunch today? A few of us from the marketing team are heading to that new sandwich place down the street at 12:30. Let me know if you want to tag along!


- Sarah
explanation: This is a completely safe, casual email from a coworker. No links, no attachments, and no urgency.

subject: Payment Declined - Update Your Payment Method
body:
Hi there,

We were unable to process the payment for your latest billing cycle. To avoid service interruption, please update your credit card information immediately.


Update Payment Info
explanation: A classic consumer phishing scam. Look at the sender email: 'netfIix' uses an uppercase 'I' instead of a lowercase 'l'. It preys on the fear of losing a service to steal credit card data.

subject: CONFIDENTIAL: Company Restructuring
body:
Dear Employee,

Due to recent market shifts, we are announcing a company-wide restructuring. Please review the attached secure document to see how your department is affected. You will need your employee login to decrypt the file.


View Restructuring_Plan.pdf
explanation: This is a highly targeted 'Spear Phishing' attack. It uses extreme emotional manipulation (fear of layoffs) to trick employees into ignoring red flags and giving up their passwords.

subject: New sign-in from Mac OS
body:
Your Google Account was just signed in to from a new Mac OS device in Russia. If you did not authorize this login, please ignore this email. If you wish to secure your account, review your devices.


The Google Workspace Team
explanation: This is a real security alert. The sender domain is genuinely '@google.com', and it specifically tells you *not* to take action if you didn't do it, rather than forcing you to click a link.

subject: Your Order #114-893201-492 is arriving today!
body:
Great news!

Your package is out for delivery. However, there is a $2.99 unpaid shipping fee. Please pay the outstanding balance to ensure the driver can drop off your package today.


Pay Shipping Fee
explanation: Amazon never holds packages hostage for a random $2.99 fee. The domain 'amzn-orders-update.com' is a fake domain meant to steal your credit card details for a tiny, believable amount.

subject: David assigned you a new task
body:
David Chen assigned a task to you:

'Review Q2 Marketing Assets'

Due Date: Next Friday.


Log into Asana to view the attached files and begin reviewing.
explanation: This is a safe notification from a real productivity tool. The sender domain is correct, and the context makes sense for a daily workflow.
